subject: linear_algebra
title: Change of Basis
contentHtml:
Understanding how to change between different coordinate systems is a fundamental concept in linear algebra.

This process involves finding the transition matrix that transforms vectors from one basis to another.

formula.latex: \[ \mathbf{A} = T^{-1} AT, \\ \text{where } T \text{ is the transition matrix} \]
formula.name: Similarity Transformation

workedExample.problemHtml: Suppose we have a vector \(\mathbf{x}\) in the standard basis, and we want to express it in the basis \(\{e_1 = (1,0), e_2 = (0,1)\}\).

steps.mathHtml: \[ T = \begin{bmatrix} e_1^T A e_1 & e_1^T A e_2 \\ e_2^T A e_1 & e_2^T A e_2 \end{bmatrix} \]
steps.explanation: The transition matrix is the matrix that transforms vectors from the standard basis to the new basis.
We multiply the original vector by the inverse of the transition matrix to get the vector in the new basis.

intuition: The change of basis formula shows that transforming vectors between different coordinate systems is equivalent to multiplying the original vector by a similarity transformation.

contentHtml:
In linear algebra, a change of basis is a fundamental concept that allows us to switch between different coordinate systems.

Given two bases \{\mathbf{v}_1,\ldots,\mathbf{v}_n\} and \{\mathbf{w}_1,\ldots,\mathbf{w}_n\}, we can find the transition matrix A such that \mathbf{w}_i = \sum_{j} A_{ij}\mathbf{v}_j.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Change of Basis
contentHtml:
The change of basis formula is a fundamental concept in linear algebra that allows us to switch between different coordinate systems.

Given two bases \(\mathbf{B}_1\) and \(\mathbf{B}_2\), we can find the transition matrix \(\mathbf{T}\) that transforms vectors from \(\mathbf{B}_1\) to \(\mathbf{B}_2\).

Find the transition matrix that transforms a vector \(\mathbf{v}_{\mathbf{B}_1} = 2\mathbf{i} + 3\mathbf{j}\) to its representation in \(\mathbf{B}_2\).
